newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Metrobank to expand consumer loans business.
newsitem.headline: Metrobank to expand consumer loans business.

text.p: Metropolitan Bank and Trust Co Inc (Metrobank) is venturing into the more lucrative but riskier consumer loans segment, bank officials said on Wednesday.
Metrobank has built its position as the country's biggest bank on the basis of its strong manufacturing and trade loans portfolio.

"We will go into consumer lending in the countryside considering that Metrobank has the most number of branches in countryside," president Antonio Abacan told analysts after the bank's annual stockholders meeting.

Concerns over rising defaults, especially in consumer-related loans for homes and cars should not deter the bank's move into the profitable segment, as Metrobank has been prudent in giving out loans, he said.
Metrobank's past due loans declined to 1.7 percent of its outstanding loan portfolio last year from 1.9 percent in 1995, senior vice president Alfredo Javellana said.
"Past due ratio has been kept stable (and it's) on the downtrend," Javellana said.
Abacan also said the bank had fully provisioned for its non-performing loans to avoid a sudden effect on its bottomline when they fall due.
Banking stocks have been battered in the past weeks after a preliminary report from the Central Bank said the industry's past due loans have been on the rise.
Consumer banking is fast becoming a very profitable segment in the banking industry due to the growing affluence in the middle-income market.
Metrobank launched two banking products in the middle of last year to cater to new car and home owners.
The bank will put up consumer lending centres in the countryside to push for the two loan products, Abacan added.
The bank planned to put up an additional 35 branches this year, in addition to the existing 335 branches nationwide.
The bank has also earmarked one billion pesos as capital expenditure for this year to be sourced from internally generated fund.
Most of this will go to branch expansion and renovation and upgrading of its equipment, Javellana said.
The bank reiterated its earlier predictions that net income for 1997 would be much higher than the 5.002 billion peso net income reached last year.
"It's a range of a low of 6.5 billion to 7.0 billion pesos," Javellana said.
